Our model takes a probabilistic view on seven ET datasets and their correction to regress catchment-level residuals using a sum-aggregated supervision. We demonstrate that our learned model has learned ET corrections that accurately generalize water cycle-closure results to unseen catchments using four global ET datasets.

In the context of climate change, the demand on water resources is increasing due to both flood and drought-related damages. Human activities impact the global water cycle, but observational uncertainties limit extreme hazard forecast capability and make it challenging to estimate human contributions to climate change trends in the context of high natural climate variability.

The water cycle is modeled through four components: precipitation (P), evapotranspiration (ET), river discharge (R), and water storage differential (dS). Closing the water cycle refers to accurately quantifying each of these components at a given spatial and temporal resolution so that they sum to zero on all spatio-temporal locations: P - ET - R + dS = 0. Among the hydrosphere components, ET remains one of the most uncertain and elusive components of Earth's water balance. It is a difficult physical process to sense as it cannot be observed directly from space, and its field measurement via eddy-covariance methods raises limited spatial representatives.

Improving ET is needed for an advanced closure of the water cycle at regional to local scales. Such improvement would translate into an improved capability to monitor and forecast extreme hazards and to attribute to human activity a more accurate part of global change. Previous studies have successfully optimized ET using the water cycle closure as a constraint, but such attempts were limited to global or catchment scales and raised limitations in generalizing ET corrections at higher scales.

We propose a method that corrects existing global ET datasets to better close the water cycle. This presents two challenges: First, the water cycle constraint includes the R component, which is only defined at the catchment scale, while we seek evaporation corrections at the pixel scale. Second, R measurements are only sparsely available, so water cycle closure errors are only available locally in space and time, while we aim to provide dense corrections to global ET datasets.

Our solution to both challenges is to use machine learning to generalize ET corrections from sparse catchment levels to dense pixel levels. We train a pixel-wise model to regress ET corrections from globally available climatic indices, which allows us to generalize the learned corrections to a dense pixel-wise resolution. Due to the nature of the R measurements, the supervision signal is defined at the catchment level, so we train our model using a sum-aggregated supervision in which we regress the sum of model outputs over catchment pixels to the catchment-level label. Our loss is defined using a maximum a posteriori (MAP) formulation, in which we use prior knowledge on ET uncertainties to guide the supervision.

We evaluate the ability of learned corrections to close the water cycle on unseen catchments and report consistent improvements across four global ET datasets. We also compare ET corrections to in-situ measurements and report improvements on three out of four datasets.

We investigate four different global ET datasets, each of which estimates ET using different methodologies and thus showcases different error patterns. These datasets are the Global Land Evaporation Amsterdam Model (GLEAM) version va.3 and vb.3, the Penman-Monteith-Leuning (PML) estimate, and the reanalysis ERA5. Our dataset contains 663 catchments and covers a time period of 192 months ranging from January 2000 to December 2015, although many months of data are missing for most catchments. In total, our dataset consists of 71,654 monthly observations.
